text: When you make a note on a paper not being useful to you, what do you include in the note? The reason I ask is that I often find papers which are not useful to me - _at that moment_. However, they could maybe become useful to me in the future so I don't want to just have a note that says "X paper was not useful to me because it was not what I was looking for" but rather something more informative... Thoughts?

elements.text: When you make a note on a paper not being useful to you, what do you include in the note? The reason I ask is that I often find papers which are not useful to me -
at that moment

. However, they could maybe become useful to me in the future so I don't want to just have a note that says "X paper was not useful to me because it was not what I was looking for" but rather something more informative... Thoughts?

text: Well, if you read enough to get a sense what it was about, write that? But not everything needs to be captured. If you only spent 30 sec on it, spending _another_ 30 sec to note that fact doesn't seem worth it to me

another
30 sec to note that fact doesn't seem worth it to me

text: I agree <@U8JP5B9T2> - that's a good point. Trying to seek efficiency and efficacy.

elements.text: I agree
- that's a good point. Trying to seek efficiency and efficacy.

text: For myself, it's almost never worth storing more than a tag or two. especially when doing a general lit scan. I'll only really need to return to papers about 2% of the time, and the effort to re-find that paper <<< the effort to capture all of my impressions of all of the papers I encounter

elements.text: For myself, it's almost never worth storing more than a tag or two. especially when doing a general lit scan. I'll only really need to return to papers about 2% of the time, and the effort to re-find that paper <<< the effort to capture all of my impressions of all of the papers I encounter

text: I agree - doing a bit of a lit review right now so I appreciate the thoughts. Trying to spend more time actually getting what I need versus spending a lot of time recording info.

elements.text: I agree - doing a bit of a lit review right now so I appreciate the thoughts. Trying to spend more time actually getting what I need versus spending a lot of time recording info.

text: I print the first page if I feel I want to come back to something and put it on my stack of first pages

elements.text: I print the first page if I feel I want to come back to something and put it on my stack of first pages

text: I categorise it in a folder in my reference manager (I currently use Zotero). Then in the future if I am revisiting a certain topic I’ll skim through that folder for potentially relevant ones first

elements.text: I categorise it in a folder in my reference manager (I currently use Zotero). Then in the future if I am revisiting a certain topic I’ll skim through that folder for potentially relevant ones first

text:
Most important kind of notes:
"This paper is not useful. It sounds like it is about X, but actually it is about Y" so I know why it looks good and don't make that mistake again.

elements.text:
Most important kind of notes:
"This paper is not useful. It sounds like it is about X, but actually it is about Y" so I know why it looks good and don't make that mistake again.

text: Yes, only there are the mistakes where it was actually about X in the first place, and I just didn’t grasp the connection

elements.text: Yes, only there are the mistakes where it was actually about X in the first place, and I just didn’t grasp the connection

text:
For example:
<http://conal.net/papers/language-derivatives/|http://conal.net/papers/language-derivatives/>

Symbolic and Automatic Differentiation of Languages
Conal Elliott, February 2021

This paper is not useful. It sounds like it is some general approach to AD that is applicable cross languages.
But actually it is talking about languages as in "sets of strings that are accepted or rejected. E.g regex".
It generalizes the idea of a derivative until a string is kind of a number. It has no bearing on calculation of derivatives on any more traditional definition of numbers.
Kinda neat though.

That's an old idea, though:

text: You can use Zotero to collect papers and use PDF annotations to keep your notes.

elements.text: You can use Zotero to collect papers and use PDF annotations to keep your notes.

text: I often use a set of keywords and give a 1-10 grade of interest to the keywords. Thus I can search by keywords later ... which I don't do often because I'm lazy ...
